8878         if (s != env->subprog_cnt) {
8879                 verbose(env, "missing bpf_line_info for %u funcs starting from func#%u\n",
8880                         env->subprog_cnt - s, s);
8881                 err = -EINVAL;
8882                 goto err_free;
8883         }
8884 
8885         prog->aux->linfo = linfo;
8886         prog->aux->nr_linfo = nr_linfo;
8887 
8888         return 0;
8889 
8890 err_free:
8891         kvfree(linfo);
8892         return err;
8893 }
8894 
8895 static int check_btf_info(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
8896                           const union bpf_attr *attr,
8897                           union bpf_attr __user *uattr)
8898 {
8899         struct btf *btf;
8900         int err;
8901 
8902         if (!attr->func_info_cnt && !attr->line_info_cnt) {
8903                 if (check_abnormal_return(env))
8904                         return -EINVAL;
8905                 return 0;
8906         }
8907 
8908         btf = btf_get_by_fd(attr->prog_btf_fd);
8909         if (IS_ERR(btf))
8910                 return PTR_ERR(btf);
8911         env->prog->aux->btf = btf;
8912 
8913         err = check_btf_func(env, attr, uattr);
8914         if (err)
8915                 return err;
8916 
8917         err = check_btf_line(env, attr, uattr);
8918         if (err)
8919                 return err;
8920 
8921         return 0;
8922 }
8923 
8924 /* check %cur's range satisfies %old's */
8925 static bool range_within(struct bpf_reg_state *old,
8926                          struct bpf_reg_state *cur)
8927 {
8928         return old->umin_value <= cur->umin_value &&
8929                old->umax_value >= cur->umax_value &&
8930                old->smin_value <= cur->smin_value &&
8931                old->smax_value >= cur->smax_value &&
8932                old->u32_min_value <= cur->u32_min_value &&
8933                old->u32_max_value >= cur->u32_max_value &&
8934                old->s32_min_value <= cur->s32_min_value &&
8935                old->s32_max_value >= cur->s32_max_value;
8936 }
8937 
8938 /* Maximum number of register states that can exist at once */
8939 #define ID_MAP_SIZE     (MAX_BPF_REG + MAX_BPF_STACK / BPF_REG_SIZE)
8940 struct idpair {
8941         u32 old;
8942         u32 cur;
8943 };
8944 
8945 /* If in the old state two registers had the same id, then they need to have
8946  * the same id in the new state as well.  But that id could be different from
8947  * the old state, so we need to track the mapping from old to new ids.
8948  * Once we have seen that, say, a reg with old id 5 had new id 9, any subsequent
8949  * regs with old id 5 must also have new id 9 for the new state to be safe.  But
8950  * regs with a different old id could still have new id 9, we don't care about
8951  * that.
8952  * So we look through our idmap to see if this old id has been seen before.  If
8953  * so, we require the new id to match; otherwise, we add the id pair to the map.
8954  */
8955 static bool check_ids(u32 old_id, u32 cur_id, struct idpair *idmap)
8956 {
8957         unsigned int i;
8958 
8959         for (i = 0; i < ID_MAP_SIZE; i++) {
8960                 if (!idmap[i].old) {
8961                         /* Reached an empty slot; haven't seen this id before */
8962                         idmap[i].old = old_id;
8963                         idmap[i].cur = cur_id;
8964                         return true;
8965                 }
8966                 if (idmap[i].old == old_id)
8967                         return idmap[i].cur == cur_id;
8968         }
8969         /* We ran out of idmap slots, which should be impossible */
8970         WARN_ON_ONCE(1);
8971         return false;
8972 }
8973 
8974 static void clean_func_state(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
8975                              struct bpf_func_state *st)
8976 {
8977         enum bpf_reg_liveness live;
8978         int i, j;
8979 
8980         for (i = 0; i < BPF_REG_FP; i++) {
8981                 live = st->regs[i].live;
8982                 /* liveness must not touch this register anymore */
8983                 st->regs[i].live |= REG_LIVE_DONE;
8984                 if (!(live & REG_LIVE_READ))
8985                         /* since the register is unused, clear its state
8986                          * to make further comparison simpler
8987                          */
8988                         __mark_reg_not_init(env, &st->regs[i]);
8989         }
8990 
8991         for (i = 0; i < st->allocated_stack / BPF_REG_SIZE; i++) {
8992                 live = st->stack[i].spilled_ptr.live;
8993                 /* liveness must not touch this stack slot anymore */
8994                 st->stack[i].spilled_ptr.live |= REG_LIVE_DONE;
8995                 if (!(live & REG_LIVE_READ)) {
8996                         __mark_reg_not_init(env, &st->stack[i].spilled_ptr);
8997                         for (j = 0; j < BPF_REG_SIZE; j++)
8998                                 st->stack[i].slot_type[j] = STACK_INVALID;
8999                 }
9000         }
9001 }
9002 
9003 static void clean_verifier_state(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
9004                                  struct bpf_verifier_state *st)
9005 {
9006         int i;
9007 
9008         if (st->frame[0]->regs[0].live & REG_LIVE_DONE)
9009                 /* all regs in this state in all frames were already marked */
9010                 return;
9011 
9012         for (i = 0; i <= st->curframe; i++)
9013                 clean_func_state(env, st->frame[i]);
9014 }
9015 
9016 /* the parentage chains form a tree.
9017  * the verifier states are added to state lists at given insn and
9018  * pushed into state stack for future exploration.
9019  * when the verifier reaches bpf_exit insn some of the verifer states
9020  * stored in the state lists have their final liveness state already,
9021  * but a lot of states will get revised from liveness point of view when
9022  * the verifier explores other branches.
9023  * Example:
9024  * 1: r0 = 1
9025  * 2: if r1 == 100 goto pc+1
9026  * 3: r0 = 2
9027  * 4: exit
9028  * when the verifier reaches exit insn the register r0 in the state list of
9029  * insn 2 will be seen as !REG_LIVE_READ. Then the verifier pops the other_branch
9030  * of insn 2 and goes exploring further. At the insn 4 it will walk the
9031  * parentage chain from insn 4 into insn 2 and will mark r0 as REG_LIVE_READ.
9032  *
9033  * Since the verifier pushes the branch states as it sees them while exploring
9034  * the program the condition of walking the branch instruction for the second
9035  * time means that all states below this branch were already explored and
9036  * their final liveness markes are already propagated.
9037  * Hence when the verifier completes the search of state list in is_state_visited()
9038  * we can call this clean_live_states() function to mark all liveness states
9039  * as REG_LIVE_DONE to indicate that 'parent' pointers of 'struct bpf_reg_state'
9040  * will not be used.
9041  * This function also clears the registers and stack for states that !READ
9042  * to simplify state merging.
9043  *
9044  * Important note here that walking the same branch instruction in the callee
9045  * doesn't meant that the states are DONE. The verifier has to compare
9046  * the callsites
9047  */
9048 static void clean_live_states(struct bpf_verifier_env *env, int insn,
9049                               struct bpf_verifier_state *cur)
9050 {
9051         struct bpf_verifier_state_list *sl;
9052         int i;
9053 
9054         sl = *explored_state(env, insn);
9055         while (sl) {
9056                 if (sl->state.branches)
9057                         goto next;
9058                 if (sl->state.insn_idx != insn ||
9059                     sl->state.curframe != cur->curframe)
9060                         goto next;
9061                 for (i = 0; i <= cur->curframe; i++)
9062                         if (sl->state.frame[i]->callsite != cur->frame[i]->callsite)
9063                                 goto next;
9064                 clean_verifier_state(env, &sl->state);
9065 next:
9066                 sl = sl->next;
9067         }
9068 }
9069 
9070 /* Returns true if (rold safe implies rcur safe) */
9071 static bool regsafe(struct bpf_reg_state *rold, struct bpf_reg_state *rcur,
9072                     struct idpair *idmap)
9073 {
9074         bool equal;
9075 
9076         if (!(rold->live & REG_LIVE_READ))
9077                 /* explored state didn't use this */
9078                 return true;
9079 
9080         equal = memcmp(rold, rcur, offsetof(struct bpf_reg_state, parent)) == 0;
9081 
9082         if (rold->type == PTR_TO_STACK)
9083                 /* two stack pointers are equal only if they're pointing to
9084                  * the same stack frame, since fp-8 in foo != fp-8 in bar
9085                  */
9086                 return equal && rold->frameno == rcur->frameno;
9087 
9088         if (equal)
9089                 return true;
9090 
9091         if (rold->type == NOT_INIT)
9092                 /* explored state can't have used this */
9093                 return true;
9094         if (rcur->type == NOT_INIT)
9095                 return false;
9096         switch (rold->type) {
9097         case SCALAR_VALUE:
9098                 if (rcur->type == SCALAR_VALUE) {
9099                         if (!rold->precise && !rcur->precise)
9100                                 return true;
9101                         /* new val must satisfy old val knowledge */
9102                         return range_within(rold, rcur) &&
9103                                tnum_in(rold->var_off, rcur->var_off);
9104                 } else {
9105                         /* We're trying to use a pointer in place of a scalar.
9106                          * Even if the scalar was unbounded, this could lead to
9107                          * pointer leaks because scalars are allowed to leak
9108                          * while pointers are not. We could make this safe in
9109                          * special cases if root is calling us, but it's
9110                          * probably not worth the hassle.
9111                          */
9112                         return false;
9113                 }
9114         case PTR_TO_MAP_VALUE:
9115                 /* If the new min/max/var_off satisfy the old ones and
9116                  * everything else matches, we are OK.
9117                  * 'id' is not compared, since it's only used for maps with
9118                  * bpf_spin_lock inside map element and in such cases if
9119                  * the rest of the prog is valid for one map element then
9120                  * it's valid for all map elements regardless of the key
9121                  * used in bpf_map_lookup()
9122                  */
9123                 return memcmp(rold, rcur, offsetof(struct bpf_reg_state, id)) == 0 &&
9124                        range_within(rold, rcur) &&
9125                        tnum_in(rold->var_off, rcur->var_off);
9126         case PTR_TO_MAP_VALUE_OR_NULL:
9127                 /* a PTR_TO_MAP_VALUE could be safe to use as a
9128                  * PTR_TO_MAP_VALUE_OR_NULL into the same map.
9129                  * However, if the old PTR_TO_MAP_VALUE_OR_NULL then got NULL-
9130                  * checked, doing so could have affected others with the same
9131                  * id, and we can't check for that because we lost the id when
9132                  * we converted to a PTR_TO_MAP_VALUE.
9133                  */
9134                 if (rcur->type != PTR_TO_MAP_VALUE_OR_NULL)
9135                         return false;
9136                 if (memcmp(rold, rcur, offsetof(struct bpf_reg_state, id)))
9137                         return false;
9138                 /* Check our ids match any regs they're supposed to */
9139                 return check_ids(rold->id, rcur->id, idmap);
9140         case PTR_TO_PACKET_META:
9141         case PTR_TO_PACKET:
9142                 if (rcur->type != rold->type)
9143                         return false;
9144                 /* We must have at least as much range as the old ptr
9145                  * did, so that any accesses which were safe before are
9146                  * still safe.  This is true even if old range < old off,
9147                  * since someone could have accessed through (ptr - k), or
9148                  * even done ptr -= k in a register, to get a safe access.
9149                  */
9150                 if (rold->range > rcur->range)
9151                         return false;
9152                 /* If the offsets don't match, we can't trust our alignment;
9153                  * nor can we be sure that we won't fall out of range.
9154                  */
9155                 if (rold->off != rcur->off)
9156                         return false;
9157                 /* id relations must be preserved */
9158                 if (rold->id && !check_ids(rold->id, rcur->id, idmap))
9159                         return false;
9160                 /* new val must satisfy old val knowledge */
9161                 return range_within(rold, rcur) &&
9162                        tnum_in(rold->var_off, rcur->var_off);
9163         case PTR_TO_CTX:
9164         case CONST_PTR_TO_MAP:
9165         case PTR_TO_PACKET_END:
9166         case PTR_TO_FLOW_KEYS:
9167         case PTR_TO_SOCKET:
9168         case PTR_TO_SOCKET_OR_NULL:
9169         case PTR_TO_SOCK_COMMON:
9170         case PTR_TO_SOCK_COMMON_OR_NULL:
9171         case PTR_TO_TCP_SOCK:
9172         case PTR_TO_TCP_SOCK_OR_NULL:
9173         case PTR_TO_XDP_SOCK:
9174                 /* Only valid matches are exact, which memcmp() above
9175                  * would have accepted
9176                  */
9177         default:
9178                 /* Don't know what's going on, just say it's not safe */
9179                 return false;
9180         }
9181 
9182         /* Shouldn't get here; if we do, say it's not safe */
9183         WARN_ON_ONCE(1);
9184         return false;
9185 }
9186 
9187 static bool stacksafe(struct bpf_func_state *old,
9188                       struct bpf_func_state *cur,
9189                       struct idpair *idmap)
9190 {
9191         int i, spi;
9192 
9193         /* walk slots of the explored stack and ignore any additional
9194          * slots in the current stack, since explored(safe) state
9195          * didn't use them
9196          */
9197         for (i = 0; i < old->allocated_stack; i++) {
9198                 spi = i / BPF_REG_SIZE;
9199 
9200                 if (!(old->stack[spi].spilled_ptr.live & REG_LIVE_READ)) {
9201                         i += BPF_REG_SIZE - 1;
9202                         /* explored state didn't use this */
9203                         continue;
9204                 }
9205 
9206                 if (old->stack[spi].slot_type[i % BPF_REG_SIZE] == STACK_INVALID)
9207                         continue;
9208 
9209                 /* explored stack has more populated slots than current stack
9210                  * and these slots were used
9211                  */
9212                 if (i >= cur->allocated_stack)
9213                         return false;
9214 
9215                 /* if old state was safe with misc data in the stack
9216                  * it will be safe with zero-initialized stack.
9217                  * The opposite is not true
9218                  */
9219                 if (old->stack[spi].slot_type[i % BPF_REG_SIZE] == STACK_MISC &&
9220                     cur->stack[spi].slot_type[i % BPF_REG_SIZE] == STACK_ZERO)
9221                         continue;
9222                 if (old->stack[spi].slot_type[i % BPF_REG_SIZE] !=
9223                     cur->stack[spi].slot_type[i % BPF_REG_SIZE])
9224                         /* Ex: old explored (safe) state has STACK_SPILL in
9225                          * this stack slot, but current has STACK_MISC ->
9226                          * this verifier states are not equivalent,
9227                          * return false to continue verification of this path
9228                          */
9229                         return false;
9230                 if (i % BPF_REG_SIZE)
9231                         continue;
9232                 if (old->stack[spi].slot_type[0] != STACK_SPILL)
9233                         continue;
9234                 if (!regsafe(&old->stack[spi].spilled_ptr,
9235                              &cur->stack[spi].spilled_ptr,
9236                              idmap))
9237                         /* when explored and current stack slot are both storing
9238                          * spilled registers, check that stored pointers types
9239                          * are the same as well.
9240                          * Ex: explored safe path could have stored
9241                          * (bpf_reg_state) {.type = PTR_TO_STACK, .off = -8}
9242                          * but current path has stored:
9243                          * (bpf_reg_state) {.type = PTR_TO_STACK, .off = -16}
9244                          * such verifier states are not equivalent.
9245                          * return false to continue verification of this path
9246                          */
9247                         return false;
9248         }
9249         return true;
9250 }
9251 
9252 static bool refsafe(struct bpf_func_state *old, struct bpf_func_state *cur)
9253 {
9254         if (old->acquired_refs != cur->acquired_refs)
9255                 return false;
9256         return !memcmp(old->refs, cur->refs,
9257                        sizeof(*old->refs) * old->acquired_refs);
9258 }
9259 
9260 /* compare two verifier states
9261  *
9262  * all states stored in state_list are known to be valid, since
9263  * verifier reached 'bpf_exit' instruction through them
9264  *
9265  * this function is called when verifier exploring different branches of
9266  * execution popped from the state stack. If it sees an old state that has
9267  * more strict register state and more strict stack state then this execution
9268  * branch doesn't need to be explored further, since verifier already
9269  * concluded that more strict state leads to valid finish.
9270  *
9271  * Therefore two states are equivalent if register state is more conservative
9272  * and explored stack state is more conservative than the current one.
9273  * Example:
9274  *       explored                   current
9275  * (slot1=INV slot2=MISC) == (slot1=MISC slot2=MISC)
9276  * (slot1=MISC slot2=MISC) != (slot1=INV slot2=MISC)
9277  *
9278  * In other words if current stack state (one being explored) has more
9279  * valid slots than old one that already passed validation, it means
9280  * the verifier can stop exploring and conclude that current state is valid too
9281  *
9282  * Similarly with registers. If explored state has register type as invalid
9283  * whereas register type in current state is meaningful, it means that
9284  * the current state will reach 'bpf_exit' instruction safely
9285  */
9286 static bool func_states_equal(struct bpf_func_state *old,
9287                               struct bpf_func_state *cur)
9288 {
9289         struct idpair *idmap;
9290         bool ret = false;
9291         int i;
9292 
9293         idmap = kcalloc(ID_MAP_SIZE, sizeof(struct idpair), GFP_KERNEL);
9294         /* If we failed to allocate the idmap, just say it's not safe */
9295         if (!idmap)
9296                 return false;
9297 
9298         for (i = 0; i < MAX_BPF_REG; i++) {
9299                 if (!regsafe(&old->regs[i], &cur->regs[i], idmap))
9300                         goto out_free;
9301         }
9302 
9303         if (!stacksafe(old, cur, idmap))
9304                 goto out_free;
9305 
9306         if (!refsafe(old, cur))
9307                 goto out_free;
9308         ret = true;
9309 out_free:
9310         kfree(idmap);
9311         return ret;
9312 }
9313 
9314 static bool states_equal(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
9315                          struct bpf_verifier_state *old,
9316                          struct bpf_verifier_state *cur)
9317 {
9318         int i;
9319 
9320         if (old->curframe != cur->curframe)
9321                 return false;
9322 
9323         /* Verification state from speculative execution simulation
9324          * must never prune a non-speculative execution one.
9325          */
9326         if (old->speculative && !cur->speculative)
9327                 return false;
9328 
9329         if (old->active_spin_lock != cur->active_spin_lock)
9330                 return false;
9331 
9332         /* for states to be equal callsites have to be the same
9333          * and all frame states need to be equivalent
9334          */
9335         for (i = 0; i <= old->curframe; i++) {
9336                 if (old->frame[i]->callsite != cur->frame[i]->callsite)
9337                         return false;
9338                 if (!func_states_equal(old->frame[i], cur->frame[i]))
9339                         return false;
9340         }
9341         return true;
9342 }
9343 
9344 /* Return 0 if no propagation happened. Return negative error code if error
9345  * happened. Otherwise, return the propagated bit.
9346  */
9347 static int propagate_liveness_reg(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
9348                                   struct bpf_reg_state *reg,
9349                                   struct bpf_reg_state *parent_reg)
9350 {
9351         u8 parent_flag = parent_reg->live & REG_LIVE_READ;
9352         u8 flag = reg->live & REG_LIVE_READ;
9353         int err;
9354 
9355         /* When comes here, read flags of PARENT_REG or REG could be any of
9356          * REG_LIVE_READ64, REG_LIVE_READ32, REG_LIVE_NONE. There is no need
9357          * of propagation if PARENT_REG has strongest REG_LIVE_READ64.
9358          */
9359         if (parent_flag == REG_LIVE_READ64 ||
9360             /* Or if there is no read flag from REG. */
9361             !flag ||
9362             /* Or if the read flag from REG is the same as PARENT_REG. */
9363             parent_flag == flag)
9364                 return 0;
9365 
9366         err = mark_reg_read(env, reg, parent_reg, flag);
9367         if (err)
9368                 return err;
9369 
9370         return flag;
9371 }
9372 
9373 /* A write screens off any subsequent reads; but write marks come from the
9374  * straight-line code between a state and its parent.  When we arrive at an
9375  * equivalent state (jump target or such) we didn't arrive by the straight-line
9376  * code, so read marks in the state must propagate to the parent regardless
9377  * of the state's write marks. That's what 'parent == state->parent' comparison
9378  * in mark_reg_read() is for.
9379  */
9380 static int propagate_liveness(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
9381                               const struct bpf_verifier_state *vstate,
9382                               struct bpf_verifier_state *vparent)
9383 {
9384         struct bpf_reg_state *state_reg, *parent_reg;
9385         struct bpf_func_state *state, *parent;
9386         int i, frame, err = 0;
9387 
9388         if (vparent->curframe != vstate->curframe) {
9389                 WARN(1, "propagate_live: parent frame %d current frame %d\n",
9390                      vparent->curframe, vstate->curframe);
9391                 return -EFAULT;
9392         }
9393         /* Propagate read liveness of registers... */
9394         BUILD_BUG_ON(BPF_REG_FP + 1 != MAX_BPF_REG);
9395         for (frame = 0; frame <= vstate->curframe; frame++) {
9396                 parent = vparent->frame[frame];
9397                 state = vstate->frame[frame];
9398                 parent_reg = parent->regs;
9399                 state_reg = state->regs;
9400                 /* We don't need to worry about FP liveness, it's read-only */
9401                 for (i = frame < vstate->curframe ? BPF_REG_6 : 0; i < BPF_REG_FP; i++) {
9402                         err = propagate_liveness_reg(env, &state_reg[i],
9403                                                      &parent_reg[i]);
9404                         if (err < 0)
9405                                 return err;
9406                         if (err == REG_LIVE_READ64)
9407                                 mark_insn_zext(env, &parent_reg[i]);
9408                 }
9409 
9410                 /* Propagate stack slots. */
9411                 for (i = 0; i < state->allocated_stack / BPF_REG_SIZE &&
9412                             i < parent->allocated_stack / BPF_REG_SIZE; i++) {
9413                         parent_reg = &parent->stack[i].spilled_ptr;
9414                         state_reg = &state->stack[i].spilled_ptr;
9415                         err = propagate_liveness_reg(env, state_reg,
9416                                                      parent_reg);
9417                         if (err < 0)
9418                                 return err;
9419                 }
9420         }
9421         return 0;
9422 }
9423 
9424 /* find precise scalars in the previous equivalent state and
9425  * propagate them into the current state
9426  */
9427 static int propagate_precision(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
9428                                const struct bpf_verifier_state *old)
9429 {
9430         struct bpf_reg_state *state_reg;
9431         struct bpf_func_state *state;
9432         int i, err = 0;
9433 
9434         state = old->frame[old->curframe];
9435         state_reg = state->regs;
9436         for (i = 0; i < BPF_REG_FP; i++, state_reg++) {
9437                 if (state_reg->type != SCALAR_VALUE ||
9438                     !state_reg->precise)
9439                         continue;
9440                 if (env->log.level & BPF_LOG_LEVEL2)
9441                         verbose(env, "propagating r%d\n", i);
9442                 err = mark_chain_precision(env, i);
9443                 if (err < 0)
9444                         return err;
9445         }
9446 
9447         for (i = 0; i < state->allocated_stack / BPF_REG_SIZE; i++) {
9448                 if (state->stack[i].slot_type[0] != STACK_SPILL)
9449                         continue;
9450                 state_reg = &state->stack[i].spilled_ptr;
9451                 if (state_reg->type != SCALAR_VALUE ||
9452                     !state_reg->precise)
9453                         continue;
9454                 if (env->log.level & BPF_LOG_LEVEL2)
9455                         verbose(env, "propagating fp%d\n",
9456                                 (-i - 1) * BPF_REG_SIZE);
9457                 err = mark_chain_precision_stack(env, i);
9458                 if (err < 0)
9459                         return err;
9460         }
9461         return 0;
9462 }
9463 
9464 static bool states_maybe_looping(struct bpf_verifier_state *old,
9465                                  struct bpf_verifier_state *cur)
9466 {
9467         struct bpf_func_state *fold, *fcur;
9468         int i, fr = cur->curframe;
9469 
9470         if (old->curframe != fr)
9471                 return false;
9472 
9473         fold = old->frame[fr];
9474         fcur = cur->frame[fr];
9475         for (i = 0; i < MAX_BPF_REG; i++)
9476                 if (memcmp(&fold->regs[i], &fcur->regs[i],
9477                            offsetof(struct bpf_reg_state, parent)))
9478                         return false;
9479         return true;
9480 }
9481 
9482 
9483 static int is_state_visited(struct bpf_verifier_env *env, int insn_idx)
9484 {
9485         struct bpf_verifier_state_list *new_sl;
9486         struct bpf_verifier_state_list *sl, **pprev;
9487         struct bpf_verifier_state *cur = env->cur_state, *new;
9488         int i, j, err, states_cnt = 0;
9489         bool add_new_state = env->test_state_freq ? true : false;
9490 
9491         cur->last_insn_idx = env->prev_insn_idx;
9492         if (!env->insn_aux_data[insn_idx].prune_point)
9493                 /* this 'insn_idx' instruction wasn't marked, so we will not
9494                  * be doing state search here
9495                  */
9496                 return 0;
9497 
9498         /* bpf progs typically have pruning point every 4 instructions
9499          * http://vger.kernel.org/bpfconf2019.html#session-1
9500          * Do not add new state for future pruning if the verifier hasn't seen
9501          * at least 2 jumps and at least 8 instructions.
9502          * This heuristics helps decrease 'total_states' and 'peak_states' metric.
9503          * In tests that amounts to up to 50% reduction into total verifier
9504          * memory consumption and 20% verifier time speedup.
9505          */
9506         if (env->jmps_processed - env->prev_jmps_processed >= 2 &&
9507             env->insn_processed - env->prev_insn_processed >= 8)
9508                 add_new_state = true;
9509 
9510         pprev = explored_state(env, insn_idx);
9511         sl = *pprev;
9512 
9513         clean_live_states(env, insn_idx, cur);
9514 
9515         while (sl) {
9516                 states_cnt++;
9517                 if (sl->state.insn_idx != insn_idx)
9518                         goto next;
9519                 if (sl->state.branches) {
9520                         if (states_maybe_looping(&sl->state, cur) &&
9521                             states_equal(env, &sl->state, cur)) {
9522                                 verbose_linfo(env, insn_idx, "; ");
9523                                 verbose(env, "infinite loop detected at insn %d\n", insn_idx);
9524                                 return -EINVAL;
9525                         }
9526                         /* if the verifier is processing a loop, avoid adding new state
9527                          * too often, since different loop iterations have distinct
9528                          * states and may not help future pruning.
9529                          * This threshold shouldn't be too low to make sure that
9530                          * a loop with large bound will be rejected quickly.
9531                          * The most abusive loop will be:
9532                          * r1 += 1
9533                          * if r1 < 1000000 goto pc-2
9534                          * 1M insn_procssed limit / 100 == 10k peak states.
9535                          * This threshold shouldn't be too high either, since states
9536                          * at the end of the loop are likely to be useful in pruning.
9537                          */
9538                         if (env->jmps_processed - env->prev_jmps_processed < 20 &&
9539                             env->insn_processed - env->prev_insn_processed < 100)
9540                                 add_new_state = false;
9541                         goto miss;
9542                 }
9543                 if (states_equal(env, &sl->state, cur)) {
9544                         sl->hit_cnt++;
9545                         /* reached equivalent register/stack state,
9546                          * prune the search.
9547                          * Registers read by the continuation are read by us.
9548                          * If we have any write marks in env->cur_state, they
9549                          * will prevent corresponding reads in the continuation
9550                          * from reaching our parent (an explored_state).  Our
9551                          * own state will get the read marks recorded, but
9552                          * they'll be immediately forgotten as we're pruning
9553                          * this state and will pop a new one.
9554                          */
9555                         err = propagate_liveness(env, &sl->state, cur);
9556 
9557                         /* if previous state reached the exit with precision and
9558                          * current state is equivalent to it (except precsion marks)
9559                          * the precision needs to be propagated back in
9560                          * the current state.
9561                          */
9562                         err = err ? : push_jmp_history(env, cur);
9563                         err = err ? : propagate_precision(env, &sl->state);
9564                         if (err)
9565                                 return err;
9566                         return 1;
9567                 }
9568 miss:
9569                 /* when new state is not going to be added do not increase miss count.
9570                  * Otherwise several loop iterations will remove the state
9571                  * recorded earlier. The goal of these heuristics is to have
9572                  * states from some iterations of the loop (some in the beginning
9573                  * and some at the end) to help pruning.
9574                  */
9575                 if (add_new_state)
9576                         sl->miss_cnt++;
9577                 /* heuristic to determine whether this state is beneficial
9578                  * to keep checking from state equivalence point of view.
9579                  * Higher numbers increase max_states_per_insn and verification time,
9580                  * but do not meaningfully decrease insn_processed.
9581                  */
9582                 if (sl->miss_cnt > sl->hit_cnt * 3 + 3) {
9583                         /* the state is unlikely to be useful. Remove it to
9584                          * speed up verification
9585                          */
9586                         *pprev = sl->next;
9587                         if (sl->state.frame[0]->regs[0].live & REG_LIVE_DONE) {
9588                                 u32 br = sl->state.branches;
9589 
9590                                 WARN_ONCE(br,
9591                                           "BUG live_done but branches_to_explore %d\n",
9592                                           br);
9593                                 free_verifier_state(&sl->state, false);
9594                                 kfree(sl);
9595                                 env->peak_states--;
9596                         } else {
9597                                 /* cannot free this state, since parentage chain may
9598                                  * walk it later. Add it for free_list instead to
9599                                  * be freed at the end of verification
9600                                  */
9601                                 sl->next = env->free_list;
9602                                 env->free_list = sl;
9603                         }
9604                         sl = *pprev;
9605                         continue;
9606                 }
9607 next:
9608                 pprev = &sl->next;
9609                 sl = *pprev;
9610         }
9611 
9612         if (env->max_states_per_insn < states_cnt)
9613                 env->max_states_per_insn = states_cnt;
9614 
9615         if (!env->bpf_capable && states_cnt > BPF_COMPLEXITY_LIMIT_STATES)
9616                 return push_jmp_history(env, cur);
9617 
9618         if (!add_new_state)
9619                 return push_jmp_history(env, cur);
9620 
9621         /* There were no equivalent states, remember the current one.
9622          * Technically the current state is not proven to be safe yet,
9623          * but it will either reach outer most bpf_exit (which means it's safe)
9624          * or it will be rejected. When there are no loops the verifier won't be
9625          * seeing this tuple (frame[0].callsite, frame[1].callsite, .. insn_idx)
9626          * again on the way to bpf_exit.
9627          * When looping the sl->state.branches will be > 0 and this state
9628          * will not be considered for equivalence until branches == 0.
9629          */
9630         new_sl = kzalloc(sizeof(struct bpf_verifier_state_list), GFP_KERNEL);
9631         if (!new_sl)
9632                 return -ENOMEM;
9633         env->total_states++;
9634         env->peak_states++;
9635         env->prev_jmps_processed = env->jmps_processed;
9636         env->prev_insn_processed = env->insn_processed;
9637 
9638         /* add new state to the head of linked list */
9639         new = &new_sl->state;
9640         err = copy_verifier_state(new, cur);
9641         if (err) {
9642                 free_verifier_state(new, false);
9643                 kfree(new_sl);
9644                 return err;
9645         }
9646         new->insn_idx = insn_idx;
9647         WARN_ONCE(new->branches != 1,
9648                   "BUG is_state_visited:branches_to_explore=%d insn %d\n", new->branches, insn_idx);
9649 
9650         cur->parent = new;
9651         cur->first_insn_idx = insn_idx;
9652         clear_jmp_history(cur);
9653         new_sl->next = *explored_state(env, insn_idx);
9654         *explored_state(env, insn_idx) = new_sl;
9655         /* connect new state to parentage chain. Current frame needs all
9656          * registers connected. Only r6 - r9 of the callers are alive (pushed
9657          * to the stack implicitly by JITs) so in callers' frames connect just
9658          * r6 - r9 as an optimization. Callers will have r1 - r5 connected to
9659          * the state of the call instruction (with WRITTEN set), and r0 comes
9660          * from callee with its full parentage chain, anyway.
9661          */
9662         /* clear write marks in current state: the writes we did are not writes
9663          * our child did, so they don't screen off its reads from us.
9664          * (There are no read marks in current state, because reads always mark
9665          * their parent and current state never has children yet.  Only
9666          * explored_states can get read marks.)
9667          */
9668         for (j = 0; j <= cur->curframe; j++) {
9669                 for (i = j < cur->curframe ? BPF_REG_6 : 0; i < BPF_REG_FP; i++)
9670                         cur->frame[j]->regs[i].parent = &new->frame[j]->regs[i];
9671                 for (i = 0; i < BPF_REG_FP; i++)
9672                         cur->frame[j]->regs[i].live = REG_LIVE_NONE;
9673         }
9674 
9675         /* all stack frames are accessible from callee, clear them all */
9676         for (j = 0; j <= cur->curframe; j++) {
9677                 struct bpf_func_state *frame = cur->frame[j];
9678                 struct bpf_func_state *newframe = new->frame[j];
9679 
9680                 for (i = 0; i < frame->allocated_stack / BPF_REG_SIZE; i++) {
9681                         frame->stack[i].spilled_ptr.live = REG_LIVE_NONE;
9682                         frame->stack[i].spilled_ptr.parent =
9683                                                 &newframe->stack[i].spilled_ptr;
9684                 }
9685         }
9686         return 0;
9687 }
9688 
9689 /* Return true if it's OK to have the same insn return a different type. */
9690 static bool reg_type_mismatch_ok(enum bpf_reg_type type)
9691 {
9692         switch (type) {
9693         case PTR_TO_CTX:
9694         case PTR_TO_SOCKET:
9695         case PTR_TO_SOCKET_OR_NULL:
9696         case PTR_TO_SOCK_COMMON:
9697         case PTR_TO_SOCK_COMMON_OR_NULL:
9698         case PTR_TO_TCP_SOCK:
9699         case PTR_TO_TCP_SOCK_OR_NULL:
9700         case PTR_TO_XDP_SOCK:
9701         case PTR_TO_BTF_ID:
9702         case PTR_TO_BTF_ID_OR_NULL:
9703                 return false;
9704         default:
9705                 return true;
9706         }
9707 }
9708 
9709 /* If an instruction was previously used with particular pointer types, then we
9710  * need to be careful to avoid cases such as the below, where it may be ok
9711  * for one branch accessing the pointer, but not ok for the other branch:
9712  *
9713  * R1 = sock_ptr
9714  * goto X;
9715  * ...
9716  * R1 = some_other_valid_ptr;
9717  * goto X;
9718  * ...
9719  * R2 = *(u32 *)(R1 + 0);
9720  */
9721 static bool reg_type_mismatch(enum bpf_reg_type src, enum bpf_reg_type prev)
9722 {
9723         return src != prev && (!reg_type_mismatch_ok(src) ||
9724                                !reg_type_mismatch_ok(prev));
9725 }
9726 
9727 static int do_check(struct bpf_verifier_env *env)
9728 {
9729         bool pop_log = !(env->log.level & BPF_LOG_LEVEL2);
9730         struct bpf_verifier_state *state = env->cur_state;
9731         struct bpf_insn *insns = env->prog->insnsi;
9732         struct bpf_reg_state *regs;
9733         int insn_cnt = env->prog->len;
9734         bool do_print_state = false;
9735         int prev_insn_idx = -1;
9736 
9737         for (;;) {
9738                 struct bpf_insn *insn;
9739                 u8 class;
9740                 int err;
9741 
9742                 env->prev_insn_idx = prev_insn_idx;
9743                 if (env->insn_idx >= insn_cnt) {
9744                         verbose(env, "invalid insn idx %d insn_cnt %d\n",
9745                                 env->insn_idx, insn_cnt);
9746                         return -EFAULT;
9747                 }
9748 
9749                 insn = &insns[env->insn_idx];
9750                 class = BPF_CLASS(insn->code);
9751 
9752                 if (++env->insn_processed > BPF_COMPLEXITY_LIMIT_INSNS) {
9753                         verbose(env,
9754                                 "BPF program is too large. Processed %d insn\n",
9755                                 env->insn_processed);
9756                         return -E2BIG;
9757                 }
9758 
9759                 err = is_state_visited(env, env->insn_idx);
9760                 if (err < 0)
9761                         return err;
9762                 if (err == 1) {
9763                         /* found equivalent state, can prune the search */
9764                         if (env->log.level & BPF_LOG_LEVEL) {
9765                                 if (do_print_state)
9766                                         verbose(env, "\nfrom %d to %d%s: safe\n",
9767                                                 env->prev_insn_idx, env->insn_idx,
9768                                                 env->cur_state->speculative ?
9769                                                 " (speculative execution)" : "");
9770                                 else
9771                                         verbose(env, "%d: safe\n", env->insn_idx);
9772                         }
9773                         goto process_bpf_exit;
9774                 }
9775 
9776                 if (signal_pending(current))
9777                         return -EAGAIN;
9778 
9779                 if (need_resched())
9780                         cond_resched();
9781 
9782                 if (env->log.level & BPF_LOG_LEVEL2 ||
9783                     (env->log.level & BPF_LOG_LEVEL && do_print_state)) {
9784                         if (env->log.level & BPF_LOG_LEVEL2)
9785                                 verbose(env, "%d:", env->insn_idx);
9786                         else
9787                                 verbose(env, "\nfrom %d to %d%s:",
9788                                         env->prev_insn_idx, env->insn_idx,
9789                                         env->cur_state->speculative ?
9790                                         " (speculative execution)" : "");
9791                         print_verifier_state(env, state->frame[state->curframe]);
9792                         do_print_state = false;
9793                 }
9794 
9795                 if (env->log.level & BPF_LOG_LEVEL) {
9796                         const struct bpf_insn_cbs cbs = {
9797                                 .cb_print       = verbose,
9798                                 .private_data   = env,
9799                         };
9800 
9801                         verbose_linfo(env, env->insn_idx, "; ");
9802                         verbose(env, "%d: ", env->insn_idx);
9803                         print_bpf_insn(&cbs, insn, env->allow_ptr_leaks);
9804                 }
9805 
9806                 if (bpf_prog_is_dev_bound(env->prog->aux)) {
9807                         err = bpf_prog_offload_verify_insn(env, env->insn_idx,
9808                                                            env->prev_insn_idx);
9809                         if (err)
9810                                 return err;
9811                 }
9812 
9813                 regs = cur_regs(env);
9814                 env->insn_aux_data[env->insn_idx].seen = env->pass_cnt;
9815                 prev_insn_idx = env->insn_idx;
9816 
9817                 if (class == BPF_ALU || class == BPF_ALU64) {
9818                         err = check_alu_op(env, insn);
9819                         if (err)
9820                                 return err;
9821 
9822                 } else if (class == BPF_LDX) {
9823                         enum bpf_reg_type *prev_src_type, src_reg_type;
9824 
9825                         /* check for reserved fields is already done */
9826 
9827                         /* check src operand */
9828                         err = check_reg_arg(env, insn->src_reg, SRC_OP);
9829                         if (err)
9830                                 return err;
9831 
9832                         err = check_reg_arg(env, insn->dst_reg, DST_OP_NO_MARK);
9833                         if (err)
9834                                 return err;
9835 
9836                         src_reg_type = regs[insn->src_reg].type;
9837 
9838                         /* check that memory (src_reg + off) is readable,
9839                          * the state of dst_reg will be updated by this func
9840                          */
9841                         err = check_mem_access(env, env->insn_idx, insn->src_reg,
9842                                                insn->off, BPF_SIZE(insn->code),
9843                                                BPF_READ, insn->dst_reg, false);
9844                         if (err)
9845                                 return err;
9846 
9847                         prev_src_type = &env->insn_aux_data[env->insn_idx].ptr_type;
9848 
9849                         if (*prev_src_type == NOT_INIT) {
9850                                 /* saw a valid insn
9851                                  * dst_reg = *(u32 *)(src_reg + off)
9852                                  * save type to validate intersecting paths
9853                                  */
9854                                 *prev_src_type = src_reg_type;
9855 
9856                         } else if (reg_type_mismatch(src_reg_type, *prev_src_type)) {
9857                                 /* ABuser program is trying to use the same insn
9858                                  * dst_reg = *(u32*) (src_reg + off)
9859                                  * with different pointer types:
9860                                  * src_reg == ctx in one branch and
9861                                  * src_reg == stack|map in some other branch.
9862                                  * Reject it.
9863                                  */
9864                                 verbose(env, "same insn cannot be used with different pointers\n");
9865                                 return -EINVAL;
9866                         }
9867 
9868                 } else if (class == BPF_STX) {
9869                         enum bpf_reg_type *prev_dst_type, dst_reg_type;
9870 
9871                         if (BPF_MODE(insn->code) == BPF_XADD) {
9872                                 err = check_xadd(env, env->insn_idx, insn);
9873                                 if (err)
9874                                         return err;
9875                                 env->insn_idx++;
9876                                 continue;
9877                         }
9878 
9879                         /* check src1 operand */
9880                         err = check_reg_arg(env, insn->src_reg, SRC_OP);
9881                         if (err)
9882                                 return err;
9883                         /* check src2 operand */
9884                         err = check_reg_arg(env, insn->dst_reg, SRC_OP);
9885                         if (err)
9886                                 return err;
9887 
9888                         dst_reg_type = regs[insn->dst_reg].type;
9889 
9890                         /* check that memory (dst_reg + off) is writeable */
9891                         err = check_mem_access(env, env->insn_idx, insn->dst_reg,
9892                                                insn->off, BPF_SIZE(insn->code),
9893                                                BPF_WRITE, insn->src_reg, false);
9894                         if (err)
9895                                 return err;
9896 
9897                         prev_dst_type = &env->insn_aux_data[env->insn_idx].ptr_type;
9898 
9899                         if (*prev_dst_type == NOT_INIT) {
9900                                 *prev_dst_type = dst_reg_type;
9901                         } else if (reg_type_mismatch(dst_reg_type, *prev_dst_type)) {
9902                                 verbose(env, "same insn cannot be used with different pointers\n");
9903                                 return -EINVAL;
9904                         }
9905 
9906                 } else if (class == BPF_ST) {
9907                         if (BPF_MODE(insn->code) != BPF_MEM ||
9908                             insn->src_reg != BPF_REG_0) {
9909                                 verbose(env, "BPF_ST uses reserved fields\n");
9910                                 return -EINVAL;
9911                         }
9912                         /* check src operand */
9913                         err = check_reg_arg(env, insn->dst_reg, SRC_OP);
9914                         if (err)
9915                                 return err;
9916 
9917                         if (is_ctx_reg(env, insn->dst_reg)) {
9918                                 verbose(env, "BPF_ST stores into R%d %s is not allowed\n",
9919                                         insn->dst_reg,
9920                                         reg_type_str[reg_state(env, insn->dst_reg)->type]);
9921                                 return -EACCES;
9922                         }
9923 
9924                         /* check that memory (dst_reg + off) is writeable */
9925                         err = check_mem_access(env, env->insn_idx, insn->dst_reg,
9926                                                insn->off, BPF_SIZE(insn->code),
9927                                                BPF_WRITE, -1, false);
9928                         if (err)
9929                                 return err;
9930 
9931                 } else if (class == BPF_JMP || class == BPF_JMP32) {
9932                         u8 opcode = BPF_OP(insn->code);
9933 
9934                         env->jmps_processed++;
9935                         if (opcode == BPF_CALL) {
9936                                 if (BPF_SRC(insn->code) != BPF_K ||
9937                                     insn->off != 0 ||
9938                                     (insn->src_reg != BPF_REG_0 &&
9939                                      insn->src_reg != BPF_PSEUDO_CALL) ||
9940                                     insn->dst_reg != BPF_REG_0 ||
9941                                     class == BPF_JMP32) {
9942                                         verbose(env, "BPF_CALL uses reserved fields\n");
9943                                         return -EINVAL;
9944                                 }
9945 
9946                                 if (env->cur_state->active_spin_lock &&
9947                                     (insn->src_reg == BPF_PSEUDO_CALL ||
9948                                      insn->imm != BPF_FUNC_spin_unlock)) {
9949                                         verbose(env, "function calls are not allowed while holding a lock\n");
9950                                         return -EINVAL;
9951                                 }
9952                                 if (insn->src_reg == BPF_PSEUDO_CALL)
9953                                         err = check_func_call(env, insn, &env->insn_idx);
9954                                 else
9955                                         err = check_helper_call(env, insn->imm, env->insn_idx);
9956                                 if (err)
9957                                         return err;
9958 
9959                         } else if (opcode == BPF_JA) {
9960                                 if (BPF_SRC(insn->code) != BPF_K ||
9961                                     insn->imm != 0 ||
9962                                     insn->src_reg != BPF_REG_0 ||
9963                                     insn->dst_reg != BPF_REG_0 ||
9964                                     class == BPF_JMP32) {
9965                                         verbose(env, "BPF_JA uses reserved fields\n");
9966                                         return -EINVAL;
9967                                 }
9968 
9969                                 env->insn_idx += insn->off + 1;
9970                                 continue;
9971 
9972                         } else if (opcode == BPF_EXIT) {
9973                                 if (BPF_SRC(insn->code) != BPF_K ||
9974                                     insn->imm != 0 ||
9975                                     insn->src_reg != BPF_REG_0 ||
9976                                     insn->dst_reg != BPF_REG_0 ||
9977                                     class == BPF_JMP32) {
9978                                         verbose(env, "BPF_EXIT uses reserved fields\n");
9979                                         return -EINVAL;
9980                                 }
9981 
9982                                 if (env->cur_state->active_spin_lock) {
9983                                         verbose(env, "bpf_spin_unlock is missing\n");
9984                                         return -EINVAL;
9985                                 }
9986 
9987                                 if (state->curframe) {
9988                                         /* exit from nested function */
9989                                         err = prepare_func_exit(env, &env->insn_idx);
9990                                         if (err)
9991                                                 return err;
9992                                         do_print_state = true;
9993                                         continue;
9994                                 }
9995 
9996                                 err = check_reference_leak(env);
9997                                 if (err)
9998                                         return err;
9999 
10000                                 err = check_return_code(env);
10001                                 if (err)
10002                                         return err;
10003 process_bpf_exit:
10004                                 update_branch_counts(env, env->cur_state);
10005                                 err = pop_stack(env, &prev_insn_idx,
10006                                                 &env->insn_idx, pop_log);
10007                                 if (err < 0) {
10008                                         if (err != -ENOENT)
10009                                                 return err;
10010                                         break;
10011                                 } else {
10012                                         do_print_state = true;
10013                                         continue;
10014                                 }
10015                         } else {
10016                                 err = check_cond_jmp_op(env, insn, &env->insn_idx);
10017                                 if (err)
10018                                         return err;
10019                         }
10020                 } else if (class == BPF_LD) {
10021                         u8 mode = BPF_MODE(insn->code);
10022 
10023                         if (mode == BPF_ABS || mode == BPF_IND) {
10024                                 err = check_ld_abs(env, insn);
10025                                 if (err)
10026                                         return err;
10027 
10028                         } else if (mode == BPF_IMM) {
10029                                 err = check_ld_imm(env, insn);
10030                                 if (err)
10031                                         return err;
10032 
10033                                 env->insn_idx++;
10034                                 env->insn_aux_data[env->insn_idx].seen = env->pass_cnt;
10035                         } else {
10036                                 verbose(env, "invalid BPF_LD mode\n");
10037                                 return -EINVAL;
10038                         }
10039                 } else {
10040                         verbose(env, "unknown insn class %d\n", class);
10041                         return -EINVAL;
10042                 }
10043 
10044                 env->insn_idx++;
10045         }
10046 
10047         return 0;
10048 }
10049 
10050 /* replace pseudo btf_id with kernel symbol address */
10051 static int check_pseudo_btf_id(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
10052                                struct bpf_insn *insn,
10053                                struct bpf_insn_aux_data *aux)
10054 {
10055         const struct btf_var_secinfo *vsi;
10056         const struct btf_type *datasec;
10057         const struct btf_type *t;
10058         const char *sym_name;
10059         bool percpu = false;
10060         u32 type, id = insn->imm;
10061         s32 datasec_id;
10062         u64 addr;
10063         int i;
10064 
10065         if (!btf_vmlinux) {
10066                 verbose(env, "kernel is missing BTF, make sure CONFIG_DEBUG_INFO_BTF=y is specified in Kconfig.\n");
10067                 return -EINVAL;
10068         }
10069 
10070         if (insn[1].imm != 0) {
10071                 verbose(env, "reserved field (insn[1].imm) is used in pseudo_btf_id ldimm64 insn.\n");
10072                 return -EINVAL;
10073         }
10074 
10075         t = btf_type_by_id(btf_vmlinux, id);
10076         if (!t) {
10077                 verbose(env, "ldimm64 insn specifies invalid btf_id %d.\n", id);
10078                 return -ENOENT;
10079         }
10080 
10081         if (!btf_type_is_var(t)) {
10082                 verbose(env, "pseudo btf_id %d in ldimm64 isn't KIND_VAR.\n",
10083                         id);
10084                 return -EINVAL;
10085         }
10086 
10087         sym_name = btf_name_by_offset(btf_vmlinux, t->name_off);
10088         addr = kallsyms_lookup_name(sym_name);
10089         if (!addr) {
10090                 verbose(env, "ldimm64 failed to find the address for kernel symbol '%s'.\n",
10091                         sym_name);
10092                 return -ENOENT;
10093         }
10094 
10095         datasec_id = btf_find_by_name_kind(btf_vmlinux, ".data..percpu",
10096                                            BTF_KIND_DATASEC);
10097         if (datasec_id > 0) {
10098                 datasec = btf_type_by_id(btf_vmlinux, datasec_id);
10099                 for_each_vsi(i, datasec, vsi) {
10100                         if (vsi->type == id) {
10101                                 percpu = true;
10102                                 break;
10103                         }
10104                 }
10105         }
10106 
10107         insn[0].imm = (u32)addr;
10108         insn[1].imm = addr >> 32;
10109 
10110         type = t->type;
10111         t = btf_type_skip_modifiers(btf_vmlinux, type, NULL);
10112         if (percpu) {
10113                 aux->btf_var.reg_type = PTR_TO_PERCPU_BTF_ID;
10114                 aux->btf_var.btf_id = type;
10115         } else if (!btf_type_is_struct(t)) {
10116                 const struct btf_type *ret;
10117                 const char *tname;
10118                 u32 tsize;
10119 
10120                 /* resolve the type size of ksym. */
10121                 ret = btf_resolve_size(btf_vmlinux, t, &tsize);
10122                 if (IS_ERR(ret)) {
10123                         tname = btf_name_by_offset(btf_vmlinux, t->name_off);
10124                         verbose(env, "ldimm64 unable to resolve the size of type '%s': %ld\n",
10125                                 tname, PTR_ERR(ret));
10126                         return -EINVAL;
10127                 }
10128                 aux->btf_var.reg_type = PTR_TO_MEM;
10129                 aux->btf_var.mem_size = tsize;
10130         } else {
10131                 aux->btf_var.reg_type = PTR_TO_BTF_ID;
10132                 aux->btf_var.btf_id = type;
10133         }
10134         return 0;
10135 }
10136 
10137 static int check_map_prealloc(struct bpf_map *map)
10138 {
10139         return (map->map_type != BPF_MAP_TYPE_HASH &&
10140                 map->map_type != BPF_MAP_TYPE_PERCPU_HASH &&
10141                 map->map_type != BPF_MAP_TYPE_HASH_OF_MAPS) ||
10142                 !(map->map_flags & BPF_F_NO_PREALLOC);
10143 }
10144 
10145 static bool is_tracing_prog_type(enum bpf_prog_type type)
10146 {
10147         switch (type) {
10148         case BPF_PROG_TYPE_KPROBE:
10149         case BPF_PROG_TYPE_TRACEPOINT:
10150         case BPF_PROG_TYPE_PERF_EVENT:
10151         case BPF_PROG_TYPE_RAW_TRACEPOINT:
10152                 return true;
10153         default:
10154                 return false;
10155         }
10156 }
10157 
10158 static bool is_preallocated_map(struct bpf_map *map)
10159 {
10160         if (!check_map_prealloc(map))
10161                 return false;
10162         if (map->inner_map_meta && !check_map_prealloc(map->inner_map_meta))
10163                 return false;
10164         return true;
10165 }
10166 
10167 static int check_map_prog_compatibility(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
10168                                         struct bpf_map *map,
10169                                         struct bpf_prog *prog)
10170 
10171 {
10172         enum bpf_prog_type prog_type = resolve_prog_type(prog);
10173         /*
10174          * Validate that trace type programs use preallocated hash maps.
10175          *
10176          * For programs attached to PERF events this is mandatory as the
10177          * perf NMI can hit any arbitrary code sequence.
10178          *
10179          * All other trace types using preallocated hash maps are unsafe as
10180          * well because tracepoint or kprobes can be inside locked regions
10181          * of the memory allocator or at a place where a recursion into the
10182          * memory allocator would see inconsistent state.
10183          *
10184          * On RT enabled kernels run-time allocation of all trace type
10185          * programs is strictly prohibited due to lock type constraints. On
10186          * !RT kernels it is allowed for backwards compatibility reasons for
10187          * now, but warnings are emitted so developers are made aware of
10188          * the unsafety and can fix their programs before this is enforced.
10189          */
10190         if (is_tracing_prog_type(prog_type) && !is_preallocated_map(map)) {
10191                 if (prog_type == BPF_PROG_TYPE_PERF_EVENT) {
10192                         verbose(env, "perf_event programs can only use preallocated hash map\n");
10193                         return -EINVAL;
10194                 }
10195                 if (IS_ENABLED(CONFIG_PREEMPT_RT)) {
10196                         verbose(env, "trace type programs can only use preallocated hash map\n");
10197                         return -EINVAL;
10198                 }
10199                 WARN_ONCE(1, "trace type BPF program uses run-time allocation\n");
10200                 verbose(env, "trace type programs with run-time allocated hash maps are unsafe. Switch to preallocated hash maps.\n");
10201         }
10202 
10203         if ((is_tracing_prog_type(prog_type) ||
10204              prog_type == BPF_PROG_TYPE_SOCKET_FILTER) &&
10205             map_value_has_spin_lock(map)) {
10206                 verbose(env, "tracing progs cannot use bpf_spin_lock yet\n");
10207                 return -EINVAL;
10208         }
10209 
10210         if ((bpf_prog_is_dev_bound(prog->aux) || bpf_map_is_dev_bound(map)) &&
10211             !bpf_offload_prog_map_match(prog, map)) {
10212                 verbose(env, "offload device mismatch between prog and map\n");
10213                 return -EINVAL;
10214         }
10215 
10216         if (map->map_type == BPF_MAP_TYPE_STRUCT_OPS) {
10217                 verbose(env, "bpf_struct_ops map cannot be used in prog\n");
10218                 return -EINVAL;
10219         }
10220 
10221         if (prog->aux->sleepable)
10222                 switch (map->map_type) {
10223                 case BPF_MAP_TYPE_HASH:
10224                 case BPF_MAP_TYPE_LRU_HASH:
10225                 case BPF_MAP_TYPE_ARRAY:
10226                         if (!is_preallocated_map(map)) {
10227                                 verbose(env,
10228                                         "Sleepable programs can only use preallocated hash maps\n");
10229                                 return -EINVAL;
10230                         }
10231                         break;
10232                 default:
10233                         verbose(env,
10234                                 "Sleepable programs can only use array and hash maps\n");
10235                         return -EINVAL;
10236                 }
10237 
10238         return 0;
10239 }
10240 
10241 static bool bpf_map_is_cgroup_storage(struct bpf_map *map)
10242 {
10243         return (map->map_type == BPF_MAP_TYPE_CGROUP_STORAGE ||
10244                 map->map_type == BPF_MAP_TYPE_PERCPU_CGROUP_STORAGE);
10245 }
10246 
10247 /* find and rewrite pseudo imm in ld_imm64 instructions:
10248  *
10249  * 1. if it accesses map FD, replace it with actual map pointer.
10250  * 2. if it accesses btf_id of a VAR, replace it with pointer to the var.
10251  *
10252  * NOTE: btf_vmlinux is required for converting pseudo btf_id.
10253  */
10254 static int resolve_pseudo_ldimm64(struct bpf_verifier_env *env)
10255 {
10256         struct bpf_insn *insn = env->prog->insnsi;
10257         int insn_cnt = env->prog->len;
10258         int i, j, err;
10259 
10260         err = bpf_prog_calc_tag(env->prog);
10261         if (err)
10262                 return err;
10263 
10264         for (i = 0; i < insn_cnt; i++, insn++) {
10265                 if (BPF_CLASS(insn->code) == BPF_LDX &&
10266                     (BPF_MODE(insn->code) != BPF_MEM || insn->imm != 0)) {
10267                         verbose(env, "BPF_LDX uses reserved fields\n");
10268                         return -EINVAL;
10269                 }
10270 
10271                 if (BPF_CLASS(insn->code) == BPF_STX &&
10272                     ((BPF_MODE(insn->code) != BPF_MEM &&
10273                       BPF_MODE(insn->code) != BPF_XADD) || insn->imm != 0)) {
10274                         verbose(env, "BPF_STX uses reserved fields\n");
10275                         return -EINVAL;
10276                 }
10277 
10278                 if (insn[0].code == (BPF_LD | BPF_IMM | BPF_DW)) {
10279                         struct bpf_insn_aux_data *aux;
10280                         struct bpf_map *map;
10281                         struct fd f;
10282                         u64 addr;
10283 
10284                         if (i == insn_cnt - 1 || insn[1].code != 0 ||
10285                             insn[1].dst_reg != 0 || insn[1].src_reg != 0 ||
10286                             insn[1].off != 0) {
10287                                 verbose(env, "invalid bpf_ld_imm64 insn\n");
10288                                 return -EINVAL;
10289                         }
10290 
10291                         if (insn[0].src_reg == 0)
10292                                 /* valid generic load 64-bit imm */
10293                                 goto next_insn;
10294 
10295                         if (insn[0].src_reg == BPF_PSEUDO_BTF_ID) {
10296                                 aux = &env->insn_aux_data[i];
10297                                 err = check_pseudo_btf_id(env, insn, aux);
10298                                 if (err)
10299                                         return err;
10300                                 goto next_insn;
10301                         }
10302 
10303                         /* In final convert_pseudo_ld_imm64() step, this is
10304                          * converted into regular 64-bit imm load insn.
10305                          */
10306                         if ((insn[0].src_reg != BPF_PSEUDO_MAP_FD &&
10307                              insn[0].src_reg != BPF_PSEUDO_MAP_VALUE) ||
10308                             (insn[0].src_reg == BPF_PSEUDO_MAP_FD &&
10309                              insn[1].imm != 0)) {
10310                                 verbose(env,
10311                                         "unrecognized bpf_ld_imm64 insn\n");
10312                                 return -EINVAL;
10313                         }
10314 
10315                         f = fdget(insn[0].imm);
10316                         map = __bpf_map_get(f);
10317                         if (IS_ERR(map)) {
10318                                 verbose(env, "fd %d is not pointing to valid bpf_map\n",
10319                                         insn[0].imm);
10320                                 return PTR_ERR(map);
10321                         }
10322 
10323                         err = check_map_prog_compatibility(env, map, env->prog);
10324                         if (err) {
10325                                 fdput(f);
10326                                 return err;
10327                         }
10328 
10329                         aux = &env->insn_aux_data[i];
10330                         if (insn->src_reg == BPF_PSEUDO_MAP_FD) {
10331                                 addr = (unsigned long)map;
10332                         } else {
10333                                 u32 off = insn[1].imm;
10334 
10335                                 if (off >= BPF_MAX_VAR_OFF) {
10336                                         verbose(env, "direct value offset of %u is not allowed\n", off);
10337                                         fdput(f);
10338                                         return -EINVAL;
10339                                 }
10340 
10341                                 if (!map->ops->map_direct_value_addr) {
10342                                         verbose(env, "no direct value access support for this map type\n");
10343                                         fdput(f);
10344                                         return -EINVAL;
10345                                 }
10346 
10347                                 err = map->ops->map_direct_value_addr(map, &addr, off);
10348                                 if (err) {
10349                                         verbose(env, "invalid access to map value pointer, value_size=%u off=%u\n",
10350                                                 map->value_size, off);
10351                                         fdput(f);
10352                                         return err;
10353                                 }
10354 
10355                                 aux->map_off = off;
10356                                 addr += off;
10357                         }
10358 
10359                         insn[0].imm = (u32)addr;
10360                         insn[1].imm = addr >> 32;
10361 
10362                         /* check whether we recorded this map already */
10363                         for (j = 0; j < env->used_map_cnt; j++) {
10364                                 if (env->used_maps[j] == map) {
10365                                         aux->map_index = j;
10366                                         fdput(f);
10367                                         goto next_insn;
10368                                 }
10369                         }
10370 
10371                         if (env->used_map_cnt >= MAX_USED_MAPS) {
10372                                 fdput(f);
10373                                 return -E2BIG;
10374                         }
10375 
10376                         /* hold the map. If the program is rejected by verifier,
10377                          * the map will be released by release_maps() or it
10378                          * will be used by the valid program until it's unloaded
10379                          * and all maps are released in free_used_maps()
10380                          */
10381                         bpf_map_inc(map);
10382 
10383                         aux->map_index = env->used_map_cnt;
10384                         env->used_maps[env->used_map_cnt++] = map;
10385 
10386                         if (bpf_map_is_cgroup_storage(map) &&
10387                             bpf_cgroup_storage_assign(env->prog->aux, map)) {
10388                                 verbose(env, "only one cgroup storage of each type is allowed\n");
10389                                 fdput(f);
10390                                 return -EBUSY;
10391                         }
10392 
10393                         fdput(f);
10394 next_insn:
10395                         insn++;
10396                         i++;
10397                         continue;
10398                 }
10399 
10400                 /* Basic sanity check before we invest more work here. */
10401                 if (!bpf_opcode_in_insntable(insn->code)) {
10402                         verbose(env, "unknown opcode %02x\n", insn->code);
10403                         return -EINVAL;
10404                 }
10405         }
10406 
10407         /* now all pseudo BPF_LD_IMM64 instructions load valid
10408          * 'struct bpf_map *' into a register instead of user map_fd.
10409          * These pointers will be used later by verifier to validate map access.
10410          */
10411         return 0;
10412 }
10413 
10414 /* drop refcnt of maps used by the rejected program */
10415 static void release_maps(struct bpf_verifier_env *env)
10416 {
10417         __bpf_free_used_maps(env->prog->aux, env->used_maps,
10418                              env->used_map_cnt);
10419 }
10420 
10421 /* convert pseudo BPF_LD_IMM64 into generic BPF_LD_IMM64 */
10422 static void convert_pseudo_ld_imm64(struct bpf_verifier_env *env)
10423 {
10424         struct bpf_insn *insn = env->prog->insnsi;
10425         int insn_cnt = env->prog->len;
10426         int i;
10427 
10428         for (i = 0; i < insn_cnt; i++, insn++)
10429                 if (insn->code == (BPF_LD | BPF_IMM | BPF_DW))
10430                         insn->src_reg = 0;
10431 }
10432 
10433 /* single env->prog->insni[off] instruction was replaced with the range
10434  * insni[off, off + cnt).  Adjust corresponding insn_aux_data by copying
10435  * [0, off) and [off, end) to new locations, so the patched range stays zero
10436  */
10437 static int adjust_insn_aux_data(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
10438                                 struct bpf_prog *new_prog, u32 off, u32 cnt)
10439 {
10440         struct bpf_insn_aux_data *new_data, *old_data = env->insn_aux_data;
10441         struct bpf_insn *insn = new_prog->insnsi;
10442         u32 prog_len;
10443         int i;
10444 
10445         /* aux info at OFF always needs adjustment, no matter fast path
10446          * (cnt == 1) is taken or not. There is no guarantee INSN at OFF is the
10447          * original insn at old prog.
10448          */
10449         old_data[off].zext_dst = insn_has_def32(env, insn + off + cnt - 1);
10450 
10451         if (cnt == 1)
10452                 return 0;
10453         prog_len = new_prog->len;
10454         new_data = vzalloc(array_size(prog_len,
10455                                       sizeof(struct bpf_insn_aux_data)));
10456         if (!new_data)
10457                 return -ENOMEM;
10458         memcpy(new_data, old_data, sizeof(struct bpf_insn_aux_data) * off);
10459         memcpy(new_data + off + cnt - 1, old_data + off,
10460                sizeof(struct bpf_insn_aux_data) * (prog_len - off - cnt + 1));
10461         for (i = off; i < off + cnt - 1; i++) {
10462                 new_data[i].seen = env->pass_cnt;
10463                 new_data[i].zext_dst = insn_has_def32(env, insn + i);
10464         }
10465         env->insn_aux_data = new_data;
10466         vfree(old_data);
10467         return 0;
10468 }
10469 
10470 static void adjust_subprog_starts(struct bpf_verifier_env *env, u32 off, u32 len)
10471 {
10472         int i;
10473 
10474         if (len == 1)
10475                 return;
10476         /* NOTE: fake 'exit' subprog should be updated as well. */
10477         for (i = 0; i <= env->subprog_cnt; i++) {
10478                 if (env->subprog_info[i].start <= off)
10479                         continue;
10480                 env->subprog_info[i].start += len - 1;
10481         }
10482 }
10483 
10484 static void adjust_poke_descs(struct bpf_prog *prog, u32 len)
10485 {
10486         struct bpf_jit_poke_descriptor *tab = prog->aux->poke_tab;
10487         int i, sz = prog->aux->size_poke_tab;
10488         struct bpf_jit_poke_descriptor *desc;
10489 
10490         for (i = 0; i < sz; i++) {
10491                 desc = &tab[i];
10492                 desc->insn_idx += len - 1;
10493         }
10494 }
10495 
10496 static struct bpf_prog *bpf_patch_insn_data(struct bpf_verifier_env *env, u32 off,
10497                                             const struct bpf_insn *patch, u32 len)
10498 {
10499         struct bpf_prog *new_prog;
10500 
10501         new_prog = bpf_patch_insn_single(env->prog, off, patch, len);
10502         if (IS_ERR(new_prog)) {
10503                 if (PTR_ERR(new_prog) == -ERANGE)
10504                         verbose(env,
10505                                 "insn %d cannot be patched due to 16-bit range\n",
10506                                 env->insn_aux_data[off].orig_idx);
10507                 return NULL;
10508         }
10509         if (adjust_insn_aux_data(env, new_prog, off, len))
10510                 return NULL;
10511         adjust_subprog_starts(env, off, len);
10512         adjust_poke_descs(new_prog, len);
10513         return new_prog;
10514 }
10515 
10516 static int adjust_subprog_starts_after_remove(struct bpf_verifier_env *env,
10517                                               u32 off, u32 cnt)
10518 {
10519         int i, j;
10520 
10521         /* find first prog starting at or after off (first to remove) */
10522         for (i = 0; i < env->subprog_cnt; i++)
10523                 if (env->subprog_info[i].start >= off)
10524                         break;
10525         /* find first prog starting at or after off + cnt (first to stay) */
10526         for (j = i; j < env->subprog_cnt; j++)
10527                 if (env->subprog_info[j].start >= off + cnt)
10528                         break;
10529         /* if j doesn't start exactly at off + cnt, we are just removing
10530          * the front of previous prog
10531          */
10532         if (env->subprog_info[j].start != off + cnt)
10533                 j--;
10534 
10535         if (j > i) {
10536                 struct bpf_prog_aux *aux = env->prog->aux;
10537                 int move;
10538 
10539                 /* move fake 'exit' subprog as well */
10540                 move = env->subprog_cnt + 1 - j;
10541 
10542                 memmove(env->subprog_info + i,
10543                         env->subprog_info + j,
10544                         sizeof(*env->subprog_info) * move);
10545                 env->subprog_cnt -= j - i;
10546 
10547                 /* remove func_info */
10548                 if (aux->func_info) {
10549                         move = aux->func_info_cnt - j;
10550 
10551                         memmove(aux->func_info + i,
10552                                 aux->func_info + j,
10553                                 sizeof(*aux->func_info) * move);
10554                         aux->func_info_cnt -= j - i;
